array.string: Emperor Napoleon I of France arrives on the island of Elba to begin his exile.
Napoleon was sent into exile on Elba, a small Mediterranean island located 260 km (160 miles) south of France and 10 km (6 miles) west of the Italian coastline.
The First Treaty of Paris is signed returning French borders to their 1792 extent.

The Treaty of Paris ended the war between France and the Sixth Coalition, part of the Napoleonic Wars. The treaty set the borders for France under the House of Bourbon and restored territories to other nations
Napoleon leaves Elba to start 100-day re-conquest of France.

Napoleon managed to sneak past his guards and somehow escape from Elba, slip past interception by a British ship, and return to France. Immediately, people and troops began to rally to the returned Emperor
Napoleon enters Paris and begins 100-day rule.
Paris welcomed him with celebration, and Louis XVIII, the new king, fled to Belgium. With Louis only just gone, Napoleon moved back into the Tuileries. The period known as the Hundred Days had begun.
June 16 1815
Battle of Ligny: Napoleon I defeated part of the Prussian army.
The battle resulted in a tactical victory for the French, but the bulk of the Prussian army survived the battle in good order and played a pivotal role two days later at the Battle of Waterloo
Battle of Waterloo leads to Napoleon Bonaparte abdicating for a second and final time.

The Battle of Waterloo was fought near Waterloo in Belgium. A French army under the command of Napoleon Bonaparte was defeated by two of the armies of the Seventh Coalition. The battle marked the end of the Napoleonic Wars.
Restoration of Louis XVIII
Louis XVIII lived in exile in Prussia, England, and Russia. Louis XVIII was placed in what he, and the French royalists, considered his rightful position.
Napoleon I of France begins his exile on St. Helena in the Atlantic Ocean.
Napoleon disembarked in St. Helena with those followers who were voluntarily accompanying him into exile: General Henri-Gratien Bertrand, grand marshal of the palace, and his wife
Naploeon Dies.
Napoleon Bonaparte, the former French ruler who once ruled an empire that stretched across Europe, dies as a British prisoner on the remote island of Saint Helena in the southern Atlantic Ocean.
